summary: The document is a confidential communication from November 9, 1995, pertaining to the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992. It details the process for releasing documents under this act, including the disclosure of individuals' names unless a credible threat to their safety or sensitive past activities can be substantiated. The communication specifically requests the assistance of a station in Mexico City to discreetly contact former employees living in Mexico, underscoring the international dimensions of the records' implications. It also outlines the criteria for individuals to challenge the release of their names, necessitating proof of potential harm.
key_findings: The document is part of compliance efforts with the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992.
It underscores the act's pro-release stance, prioritizing public disclosure unless a credible threat is identified.
The request for station assistance in Mexico City highlights the global reach of the records' impact.
It specifies the procedure for individuals to oppose the release of their names, requiring evidence of possible threats to safety or sensitive historical activities.
keywords: President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act
